query.queryString: (/article/relations/categories/collection/code='resultsPack,projectsInfoPack,brief' OR (/result/relations/categories/collection/code='deliverable,publication' OR contenttype='project')) AND ('SUSTAINABILITY' OR 'INNOVATION' OR 'MULTI-CRITERIA')

result.title: D6.3.1 Impact measurement and monitoring
result.description: This deliverable presents a comprehensive framework for measuring the impact of the ExcellEnt project as well as outlining the monitoring process that will be employed to ensure that the project stays on track in terms of meeting its goals and objectivesThe impact measurement framework is designed to assess the various ways in which the project contributes to the wider community and to evaluate its overall effectiveness By defining a set of measurable indicators and metrics we can objectively assess the success of the project and identify areas for improvementIn addition to the impact measurement framework this deliverable also presents the monitoring process that will be put in place to track the progress of the project This process will include regular data collection analysis and reporting to ensure that the project is achieving its objectives and producing the desired results

project.title: Excellency in Entrepreneurship: Expanding European entrepreneurship by boosting youth (self) employability and promoting a sharing resources culture

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.

category.title: Legal Basis
category.description: Programme: Legal basis for research funding

category.title: Topic
category.description: Programme: Part of the Commission work programme implementing legal basis

category.title: Legal Basis
category.description: Programme: Legal basis for research funding

result.title: D3.1 Operationalisation of the European Entrepreneurship Academy
result.description: This deliverable includes the specification and operationalisation of the Academy platform performed in T3.1 to effectively host community members and deliver added value resources and services. The platform will have the following features: i) landing page of the project activities and services; ii) on-line community; iii) on-line training space, iv) webinars and MOOCs on various entrepreneurial topics; v) marketplace for matchmaking; vi) access knowledge points (training, coaching, mentorship); and vii) other sources of funding and visibility.

result.title: D5.2.1 Communication and Dissemination actions report - first report
result.description: This deliverable will be the output of Task 52 will be constantly updated during the project implementation M6 M18 and M30 and will include the detailed planning of all communication activities of the Excellent campaign and promotion in a systematic manner Definition and implementation of Dissemination plan channels measures and tools in the first version Continuously updated and synchronised with the project activities Joint events with relevant initiatives project promotion

category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.

article.title: Diagnosis of hidden Alzheimer’s disease
article.teaser: A significant proportion of patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) remains undiagnosed or diagnosed at a late stage. Through a series of initiatives, the MOPEAD project aims to contribute to its timely diagnosis.

section.sectionBody: Emerging evidence indicates that early AD diagnosis offers an optimal opportunity for intervention, leading to significant health, social and economic benefits.

The EU and industry-funded https://www.mopead.eu/ (MOPEAD) project designed four prescreening strategies to unveil dementia hidden cases and raise awareness in the general public and health professionals on the importance of early diagnosis of cognitive impairment. “The initiatives were designed to be complementary, targeting different populations,” explains project coordinator Mercè Boada.
These activities included a web-based initiative for the identification of individuals at risk of dementia and an open house memory clinic accessible to anyone worried about their memory. The project also developed protocols for the early detection of cognitive decline at primary care practices or diabetologist tertiary units. Individuals identified through these initiatives with a risk of dementia underwent a harmonised evaluation to obtain an accurate clinical diagnosis.
As envisaged, population-based initiatives enrolled younger individuals with better cognitive status compared to patient-based strategies at primary care or diabetic clinics. The proportion of positive prescreening results reflected this observation with the web-based initiative exhibiting 36 % of positive cases compared to the diabetic clinic initiative that showed 58 % positive individuals. Following clinical evaluation of the positive cases from the diabetic clinic, 84 % of the cases were confirmed.
Interestingly, the number of individuals who participated in the web-based initiative alone was greater than the sum of all other initiatives together. This clearly indicated the power of e-solutions in the healthcare of cognitive deficits. Nonetheless, the choice of the dementia prescreening strategy depends on the specific goals, the characteristics of the target population and available resources. “Although budget may pose a significant limitation to implementing a combination of these strategies, it is essential to overcome the problem of dementia underdiagnosis,” emphasises Boada.

Worldwide, https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/dementia (approximately 50 million people are living with dementia) and the number is estimated to increase. Late diagnosis is associated with irreversible neuronal damage, for which there is no cure. Apart from the timely diagnosis of cognitive deficits, MOPEAD is expected to give access to treatments early on, including experimental protocols.
Partners tested the MOPEAD strategies in five different European academic institutions, with varying outcomes. Efforts to standardise dementia early detection protocols across Europe will not only improve citizen health but also positively affect the overall quality of research in the field by facilitating patient recruitment in clinical trials. This increases the chances of finding new effective treatments.
While population-based strategies have a great potential to prescreen large numbers of individuals, patient-based strategies reach individuals who regularly visit the health services and may be at greater risk of dementia. MOPEAD dissemination activities such as educational leaflets and infographics will definitively help increase awareness of the problem and improve disease management. By promoting a paradigm shift towards earlier dementia diagnosis, partners hope to overcome existing barriers that contribute to delayed diagnosis, including limited resources and stigmatisation.

article.keywords: MOPEAD, dementia, diagnosis, prescreening, diabetic clinic, Alzheimer’s disease

article.title: Igniting a global dementia prevention movement
article.teaser: An innovative headband which may detect early signs of dementia and offer advice to mitigate risk through a proprietary app has been developed by an EU-supported project.

section.sectionBody:
Dementia is a neurodegenerative disease that can stop people carrying out basic daily functions. It affects over 10 million people in Europe alone. The World Health Organization expects this figure to double by 2030.
“Radical change is needed as one in three people born today are expected to develop dementia in their lifetime. Solutions are therefore needed to reduce numbers impacted in the next elderly generation,” says Melissa May Kapoor, CEO and founder of https://mind-medtech.com/ (Mind Over Matter Medtech Ltd).
Diagnosing dementia is difficult, however, and often is only recognised once symptoms have advanced. The EU-funded DEMPREV project, run by the British company Mind Over Matter Medtech, is hoping to kick-start a global movement for the prevention of the disease, by identifying biomarkers that reveal a risk of future development. DEMPREV is focusing on brain inflammation.
Chronic systemic inflammation can occur because of diabetes, long-term poor diet, chronic stress, lack of sleep and other known lifestyle risks for dementia. The resulting inflammatory mediators travelling in the blood can cause the https://qbi.uq.edu.au/brain/brain-anatomy/what-blood-brain-barrier (blood-brain barrier) to become more permeable.
“This can lead to these inflammatory mediators entering the brain permanently and causing damage to the brain cells. It is a consequence of this damage on the function of the brain that our system aims to detect,” explains Kapoor, DEMPREV project coordinator.
The team investigated the feasibility of developing a non-invasive neuroimaging solution that detects unique information about an individual’s risk of developing dementia. And the project wanted to find out if this solution could be manufactured at a price that potential customers would be willing to pay.

The low-cost technology incorporates a headband with a small number of novel neuroimaging sensors. It is believed that these sensors may allow the level of brain inflammation, an established biomarker of future dementia risk, to be inferred in a non-invasive manner in primary care or community settings.
The vision is for the headband to be used in conjunction with software that assesses an individual’s clinical dementia risk factors. These include smoking, BMI and diet, among others. Combining dementia risk information detected by the headband with clinical risk factor information has potential to create a step change in the sensitivity and specificity with which an individual’s dementia risk can be estimated.

Drawing on detailed assessment by the software, individuals could be prescribed methods for changing and improving their lifestyle in ways which could reduce the risk of developing dementia by up to 50 %. The project is also developing a solution to assist with this, namely a behaviour change app. “Our system provides small, personalised daily behaviour change steps targeting the risk factors that help reduce the user’s dementia risk score,” adds Kapoor.
The project has been working on the app through the period of COVID-19 lockdown in the United Kingdom, finalising its functionality and adding in new modules that will increase compliance with the behaviour change programmes. The team then plans to pilot the app to collect evidence of clinical effectiveness and business model viability.
Additionally, Mind Over Matter Medtech is planning for a future project to complete the dataset needed to prove the neuroimaging headband concept. “We will then be seeking to raise funds to develop a wireless version of the headband and conduct a trial validating the headband using an MRI scanner,” says Kapoor.

article.keywords: DEMPREV, dementia, prevention, scanner, inflammation, brain, headband, software
